objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to develop PROTEUS, a fully automated system for scientific discovery from raw proteomics data using large language models (LLMs). The authors aim to automate complex proteomics analysis workflows and hypothesis generation to accelerate scientific discovery in proteomics research.
objective.evidence: In this paper, we present PROTEUS, a fully automated system for scientific discovery from raw proteomics data. PROTEUS uses large language models (LLMs) to perform hierarchical planning, execute specialized bioinformatics tools, and iteratively refine analysis workflows to generate high-quality scientific hypotheses.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in automating entire omics research procedures, which are currently limited by human intervention and lack flexibility and comprehensiveness.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Previous research on using LLMs to enhance omics research has largely been confined to isolated steps within the complex research process... they lack the flexibility and comprehensiveness required for automating entire omics research procedures.

answer: PROTEUS automates the entire proteomics research process from raw data to hypothesis generation without human intervention.
The system integrates large language models with specialized bioinformatics tools to perform hierarchical planning and iterative refinement.
PROTEUS is capable of generating novel, evaluable hypotheses that align with existing literature while proposing new insights.
The system's flexible architecture allows seamless integration of diverse analysis tools and adaptation to different proteomics data types.
evidence: PROTEUS uses large language models (LLMs) to perform hierarchical planning, execute specialized bioinformatics tools, and iteratively refine analysis workflows to generate high-quality scientific hypotheses.
The system’s flexible architecture facilitates seamless integration of diverse analysis tools and adaptation to different proteomics data types.
Results demonstrate that PROTEUS consistently produces reliable, logically coherent results that align well with existing literature while also proposing novel, evaluable hypotheses.

tools.name: Llama 3.1
tools.description: Used as the backbone architecture for orchestrating the analysis process.
tools.evidence: We predominantly adopt the state-of-the-art open-source LLM, Llama 3.1 [7], as our backbone architecture.

tools.name: CATALYST
tools.description: Used for FlowSOM clustering and cell type annotation.
tools.evidence: We use the CATALYST [74] package to execute the FlowSOM [75] algorithm, a self-organizing map-based method designed for flow or mass cytometry data.

tools.name: diffcyt
tools.description: Used for differential abundance and expression analysis.
tools.evidence: We use the edgeR [78] algorithm in the diffcyt [79] package to perform differential analysis of cell type abundances over different sample characteristics.
